intro: Linum mucronatum subsp. assyriacum, commonly known as the Assyrian flax, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender stems and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, blue to violet flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It prefers well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or arid environments. This subspecies is valued for its ornamental appeal and historical significance in ancient textile production.
